review.title: Particle Filtering on the Audio Localization Manifold
review.abstract: We present a novel particle filtering algorithm for tracking a moving sound source using a microphone array. If there are N microphones in the array, we track all $N \choose 2$ delays with a single particle filter over time. Since it is known that tracking in high dimensions is rife with difficulties, we instead integrate into our particle filter a model of the low dimensional manifold that these delays lie on. Our manifold model is based off of work on modeling low dimensional manifolds via random projection trees [1]. In addition, we also introduce a new weighting scheme to our particle filtering algorithm based on recent advancements in online learning. We show that our novel TDOA tracking algorithm that integrates a manifold model can greatly outperform standard particle filters on this audio tracking task.

sections.heading: 2 Time Delay of Arrival
sections.text: A very popular method for estimating a TDOA audio frame from a pair of microphones is the application of a generalized correlation technique known as phase transformation, also known as PHAT [13]. PHAT is a normalized cross-correlation technique that removes orders of amplitude information from the audio signals, focusing on the alignment of the phase components. If you define Rp (τ) as the PHAT correlation between the microphone pair p during delayed viewing, then the TDOA is often estimated according to ∆ p = argmax τ Rp (τ) (1). However, in a reverberating environment, there are often fake Rp peaks either through line noise or multipath reflections. In these cases, the true TDOA may not be the largest peak in the PHAT correlation. By using particle filters, we are able to use this secondary peak information in formulating a probability function that includes the whole of the Rp observation.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: The recordings were made at 16 kHz on a 7-microphone array, which is part of an interactive display located in a large public lobby, and the room measures approximately 10m x 13m x 5m. Four of the microphones are located at the corners of the display, which is mounted on one of the walls in the room, and the three remaining microphones are located on the ceiling of the room. For more details on the microphone set-up and the room see [4, 7]. To build a PD tree, we first collected a set of TDOA vectors from our microphone array. We did this by moving a white noise source around the room, near typical places where sitting or standing people would interact with the screen. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we examine particle filtering methods for tracking TDOA vectors for moving sound sources, a key problem that needs to be solved for audio localization and PA applications. We present a model of diversity based on spatial distribution trees that alleviates the problem of high-dimensional tracking with particle filters. We also present a new version of a particle filter based on results from online learning that competes with conventional particle filters in this task and exhibits properties that are attractive for many real-world problems.
